items.title: Is textract dead or alive (under active development)?
items.body:
I see that the last commit is more than half a year ago, that the build and the docs are failing. This indicates that textract might not be under active development.

You might want to add the [trove classifier](https://pypi.org/classifiers/) `Development Status :: 7 - Inactive` to the project.

items.title: Is textract still being maintained?
items.body:
Hi. I see that most issues are not commented by contributors and there are also many pull requests that would only require minimal work to test and accept. As a result the last commit in the master branch is nearly two years old.
Is someone still maintaining textract?
Given the popularity of this project, I think it should not die.

textract 1.6.1 has requirement six==1.10.0, but you'll have six 1.12.0 which is incompatible.

items.body:
#### Description
The git repository has the following python requirements in `requirements/python`

```
argcomplete==1.8.2
chardet==3.0.4
python-pptx==0.6.6
#pdfminer.six <-- go back to this after the shebang fix is released (see https://github.com/goulu/pdfminer/issues/27)
https://github.com/goulu/pdfminer/zipball/e6ad15af79a26c31f4e384d8427b375c93b03533#egg=pdfminer.six

beautifulsoup4==4.6.0

SpeechRecognition==3.7.1
https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/zipball/master
six==1.10.0
pocketsphinx==0.1.3
```

yet the tar.gz file hosted at [PyPi](https://pypi.org/project/textract/) still has the following requirements

```
argcomplete==1.8.2
chardet==2.3.0
python-pptx==0.6.5
#pdfminer.six <-- go back to this after the shebang fix is released (see https://github.com/goulu/pdfminer/issues/27)

beautifulsoup4==4.5.3

EbookLib==0.15
SpeechRecognition==3.6.3
https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/zipball/master
six==1.10.0
pocketsphinx==0.1.3
```

#### To reproduce
Run `pip install textract` or `poetry add textract`

#### Tasks
- [ ] Update requirements for textract 1.6.1

items.title: textract 1.6.0 with chardet 3.0.4 - why is it working and whats going to break?
items.body:
I had issues parsing UTF-8 encoded .rtf-s using Textract 1.6.0 and 1.6.1. Running on Ubuntu 18 & Debian Stretch with Python version 3.5 (Anaconda).

It appears that both chardet 2.1.1 and 2.3.0 failed to correctly predict the encoding, which resulted in a decoding error:

> File "/home/rsirel/.conda/envs/p35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/textract/parsers/utils.py", line 65, in decode
> return text.decode(result['encoding'])
>  File "/home/rsirel/.conda/envs/p35/lib/python3.5/encodings/cp1255.py", line 15, in decode
> return codecs.charmap_decode(input,errors,decoding_table)
> UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0xfc in position 1514: character maps to <undefined>

However, when used with chardet 3.04, the content gets parsed with no errors. Furthermore, when testing with several other documents as well, everything seemed to work fine.

Hence the question: what is likely to break when using chardet 3.0.4? Any particular reasons to avoid it?

items.title: Attempting to extract text from mp3/ogg
items.body:
I do something like this:

$ time python -c 'import textract; a=textract.process("A long test of mp3.mp3"); print(a)'

What I get returned is:

b'\n'

It takes 5 minutes to get this.

I have seen this on mp3 or ogg files greater than 5 minutes. However, on a short mp3 less than 2 minutes I get the text accurately and it works well.. Is this a limitation, memory issue, some other error? 

Thank you!

items.title: upgrade dependency marked to version >= 0.3.9 to fix vulnerabity
items.body:
Github just notified me that textract uses the npm package _marked_@_0.3.6_ which has security vulnerabilities [https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-1000427](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-1000427).
To fix it just update the dependency to _marked_ to version 0.3.9 or higher.

items.title: Missing ExtractMsg and other link dependencies
items.body:
Hello,

After making _pip install textract_ these two dependencies are missing:
https://github.com/goulu/pdfminer/zipball/e6ad15af79a26c31f4e384d8427b375c93b03533#egg=pdfminer.six
https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/zipball/master

That's why msg_parser.py fails with exception:
`No module named ExtractMsg`

Should it be fixed?

Thank you.

items.title: Security Vulnerability
items.body:
I hate to drop that but I couldn't get any traction otherwise:
I found an OS command injection back in June and I contributed a fix in [PR 114](https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract/pull/114)

Parsing a file with a malicious name leads to arbitrary OS command injection, this is especially risky when parsing user-supplied files on a server (e.g. uploaded files)

import textract
import sys
import os

# create a file with a malicious name and arbitrary content
fileName = './test";gnome-calculator;#.pdf'
file = open(fileName,'w+')
file.write('Pierre Ernst, Salesforce')
file.close()

# parse newly created file
text = textract.process(fileName)
print text

# cleanup
os.remove(fileName);

items.title: textract needs a co-maintainer
items.body:
I am totally floored by how much of a community effort `textract` has become over the last few years. We've added loads of new features, gone through a refactoring or two, and made several meaningful enhancements. Thanks to everyone who has helped make this happen!

Recently, my day job (which I love!) has kept me sufficiently busy that I've become irresponsibly delayed in my response to PRs that will benefit everyone. As a result, I am actively looking for someone to help me co-maintain this project. Realistically, it's probably only an hour or two of effort per week, if that. 

If you are interested, please let me know. I'd prefer that you express your interest by leaving a comment on this issue. If you'd rather be considered in private, it shouldn't be too hard to find my email address in the commit logs or to find me on Twitter.

I'm hoping to find a co-maintainer in the next week or two. Thanks for your consideration!

items.title: contents in tables in incorrect order in docx files
items.body: This came up when addressing @jsmith-mploir's #92. To get things up and running quickly, we took the first step of getting the table contents to be extracted, but there is an additional step that can/should be done, which is to make sure that the text is in the correct order. There is currently an example of this in `tests/docx/paragraphs_and_tables.docx` and you can see the current (incorrectly ordered) output in `tests/docx/paragraphs_and_tables.txt`. #92 has a few links that might be helpful for addressing this, but I didn't want to hold up the next release any more than I already had.

items.title: More audio file-type support
items.body:
I've coded in '.wav' file-type support - PR #56.
Let's get more audio file-types supported!

Ideas:
- Keep this extractor in place, and convert other types to '.wav' before use.
  - This allows us to continue to use Google's Speech Recognition system, which is pretty good.
  - Use a simple file cloud-conversion API to convert everything to '.wav'.
- Write different code, and use specialized tools for each type.
  - This might result in faster extraction times (no conversion delay).
  - Might yield better results in some cases.
  - However, more code will need to be written and maintained.

I'm open to all suggestions!

items.title: odt parser and list elements
items.body:
There appears to be something strange going on with the odt parser. In [this document](https://www.dropbox.com/s/eavnukoyxkh028t/standardized_text.odt?dl=0), for example, I'd expect the textract output to be something like:

```
the quick 
brown fox
jumps
over
the
lazy dog
```

but instead we get something like this:

```
the quick
brown fox
jumps 
over 
the 
lazy dog
jumps over the 
```

It looks like the list elements appear twice and out of order, probably because of how we are extracting the text—first extracting `text:p` elements, then extracting `text:h` elements, and finally extracting `text:list` elements.

items.title: remove tesseract version info from extracted text
items.body:
It looks like every image processed with textract has a message like `Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v3.02 with Leptonica` at the beginning. This appears to be printed to standard out and is not a reflection of the text that is actually in the document:

``` shell
vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ textract tests/gif/i_heart_gifs.gif
Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v3.02 with Leptonica
TEXT


vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ tesseract tests/gif/i_heart_gifs.gif kk.txt
Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v3.02 with Leptonica
vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ cat kk.txt.txt 
TEXT

vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ tesseract tests/jpg/i_heart_jpegs.jpg gg.txt
Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v3.02 with Leptonica
vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ tesseract tests/jpg/i_heart_jpegs.jpg gg.txt > kk
vagrant@dev:/vagrant$ cat kk
Tesseract Open Source OCR Engine v3.02 with Leptonica
```

This should be a simple fix of just redirecting the output of the tesseract command in a smarter way, but I'm in the middle of something else and thought I'd create a placeholder issue in case someone else has the time to address it.
